intro.title: Stress Type Test
intro.sub: Where does your body hold stress?
intro.desc: Tap your stress zones on a body map, then react to 8 real-life scenarios. Discover your unique stress type!

body.title: Where do you feel stress?
body.instruction: Tap all the areas where you feel tension, pain, or discomfort when stressed. Select at least 2.

scenarios.s1: You have a major presentation tomorrow and you're completely unprepared.
scenarios.s2: A close friend suddenly stops responding to your messages for no reason.
scenarios.s3: Your boss calls out your mistake in front of the entire team.
scenarios.s4: Your computer crashes right before a deadline and all your work is gone.
scenarios.s5: At a family gathering, relatives constantly compare your life choices to others.
scenarios.s6: A coworker presents your idea as their own and gets praised for it.
scenarios.s7: You receive a large, unexpected bill you can't easily afford.
scenarios.s8: You've barely slept for 3 days and today's schedule is packed.

overthinker.name: The Overthinker
overthinker.subtitle: A mind that never stops spinning
overthinker.desc: You are The Overthinker â€” your stress lives in your head. Tension clusters around your head, eyes, and jaw, and when faced with pressure, you tend to freeze or flee. You replay worst-case scenarios on loop and delay action until everything feels perfect. This type is prone to analysis paralysis, so the key is to get out of your head and into your body.
tips: Set a daily 15-minute 'worry window' â€” postpone all worrying outside of it
Practice 4-7-8 breathing (inhale 4s, hold 7s, exhale 8s) to reset your mind
Write worries on paper and sort them into 'controllable' vs 'uncontrollable'

volcano.name: The Volcano
volcano.subtitle: Stress that explodes as anger
volcano.desc: You are The Volcano â€” tension accumulates in your neck, shoulders, and back until stress erupts as anger. You react strongly to injustice and follow a cycle of suppressing emotions until they burst. Anger itself is natural, but uncontrolled outbursts can damage relationships and health. The key is finding healthy outlets before the pressure becomes unbearable.
tips: When anger rises, remove yourself immediately and count to 10 slowly
Use regular aerobic exercise to release accumulated stress energy
Keep an anger journal to identify your consistent triggers

pleaser.name: The People-Pleaser
pleaser.subtitle: Carries anxiety in the chest and gut
pleaser.desc: You are The People-Pleaser â€” stress concentrates in your chest and stomach as you absorb other people's emotions as your own. You struggle to say no and push yourself to meet everyone's expectations until you collapse. When faced with conflict, you run or sacrifice yourself. Building healthy boundaries and prioritizing your own needs is the most important thing you can do.
tips: Practice saying 'no' once a day, starting with small things
Consciously separate other people's problems from your own
Reserve at least 10 minutes daily that are exclusively for yourself

walkingdead.name: The Walking Dead
walkingdead.subtitle: Total exhaustion across the entire body
walkingdead.desc: You are The Walking Dead â€” fatigue and tension have spread across your entire body, from your lower back to your hips and legs. Your energy is completely depleted; when stress hits, you either shut down or collapse. Rest doesn't recharge you, and things you once loved feel meaningless. Left unchecked, this can evolve into chronic depression or serious illness â€” self-care must be your top priority right now.
tips: Schedule 30 minutes of 'doing absolutely nothing' in your calendar daily
Set strict digital boundaries â€” turn off all work notifications after hours
Tell someone you trust honestly: 'I'm struggling' â€” don't carry it alone

white-noise.desc: Ambient sounds for sleep and focus
